title: Protocol to capture transcription factor-mediated 3D chromatin interactions using affinity tag-based BL-HiChIP
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Construction of Tet-On-FLAG tagged MyoD cells (for MyoD-induced transdifferentiation)
Timing: 2–3 weeks
This step involves the lentivirus packaging before transduction on C3H/10T1/2 cell line. In addition, the plasmid contains a puromycin resistance cassette, enabling puromycin selection of cells that have integrated the 3× FLAG-tagged full-length mouse MyoD cDNA from the Tetracycline Responsive Element (TRE) promoter.
Construction of viral vectors.
Separately digest pUC57-FLAG-MyoD1 and pCW-Cas9 backbone plasmids with NheI and BamHI restriction enzymes.
Pipette and combine all the reagents according to the table into a 200 μL PCR tube.
Mix well by gently pipetting up and down and spin them down to collect the entire reaction mixture at the bottom of the tube.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_11.csv
Incubate the reaction for 2 h at 37°C on a PCR machine.
Preparation of the 2% [w/v] agarose gel
Mix 1.6 g of agarose and 80 mL 1× TAE buffer and boil in a microwave until the agarose dissolves completely.
Pour the gel in the clean standard gel casting tray with a comb until the gel cools to approximate 50°C.
Allow the gel to solidify.
Load the digested sample along with loading buffer that has been added with GelRed (1:10000) and a suited DNA marker.
Run electrophoresis in 1× TAE buffer at 120 V for approximate 20 min to ensure adequate separation of restriction fragments.
Visualize DNA fragments on a standard UV table. Purify FLAG-MyoD1 and backbone vector (called pCW) fragments from agarose gel (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B), following the manufacturer’s instructions of the Gel Extraction Kit (Omega, #D2500).
Measure DNA concentration using NanoDrop.
Ligate the pCW with the FLAG-MyoD1 fragment. Pipette and combine all the reagents according to the table into a 1.5 mL tube and mix by pipetting. Incubate 12–16 h at 16°C.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_12.csv

Note: The DNA amount of FLAG-MyoD1 fragment should be calculated with ligation calculator (https://nebiocalculator.neb.com/#!/ligation[href=https://nebiocalculator.neb.com/#!/ligation]). The desired molar ratio of insert fragment versus vector is 3:1.
Transform DH5α E.coli competent cells with ligation reaction.
Thaw a required amount of DH5α E.coli competent cells, stored at -80°C, on ice. For each transformation, use 50 μL of DH5α cells.
Add 5 μL of vector-plus ligation reaction to 50 μL of competent cells, gently mix with a pipette and then incubate on ice for 5 min.
Heat shock at 42°C for 1 min and 30 s in a water bath and transfer to ice immediately for 2 min.
Plate the transformation mixes onto LB agar plates with Ampicillin (100 μg/mL), using a sterile loop and incubate at 37°C for 16–18 h in a bacterial incubator.
On the next day, check for growth of bacterial colonies on the agar plate.
Pick 10 single colonies from the plate and inoculate in 1 mL of LB medium supplied with 100 μg/mL Ampicillin.
Incubate in a shaker at 37°C for 4–6 h.
After 4–6 h, check the turbidity of the medium and it should appear cloudy otherwise the competent cells fail to grow. Take out 200 μL of the colonies medium that appear cloudy separately and send them directly to the company without any processing for Sanger sequencing.
For Sanger sequencing, use the sequence of the backbone vector which is near the ligation site (here we used 5′-TAGTGAACCGTCAGATCGCCTG-3′ sequence) to verify the existence of FLAG-MyoD1 fragment. Once the FLAG-MyoD1 sequence is available, the colony is identified as the positive.
Expand the positive colony in 25 mL of LB medium supplied with 100 μg/mL Ampicillin to isolate viral vector DNA.

Viral vector DNA may be isolated one according to the manufacturer’s instructions of E.Z.N.A. Endo-Free Plasmid Mini Kit II (Omega, #D6950-01).
Prepare 293T cells for transfection.
Seed 4×106 293T cells in a 10-cm plate using growth medium so that they will be 70% confluent the next day.
jetPRIME transfection.
Prepare the following mixture in 1.5 mL sterile tube in the clean bench. Retrieve the 10-cm plate from the incubator and put it into the clean bench. Remove the growth medium and add 5 mL of transfection medium. Then add the prepared transfection mixture into plate and mix gently. Put the 10-cm plate back into cell incubator.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_13.csv
4 h after transfection, aspirate the medium and add 10 mL pre-warmed (37°C) transfection medium to the plate.
24 h after transfection, retrieve the plate from incubator and directly add 10 mL pre-warmed transfection medium to the plate. Return the plate to the incubator.
60 h after transfection, harvest the lentivirus.
Critical: At this point, infective lentivirus is present in the supernatant. Thus, wear safety sleeves, bleach all tubes that have come in contact with viral material, and follow the safety procedures.
Collect the medium (∼20 mL) from 1 × 10 cm plate into 50 mL tube.
Centrifuge at 4000 × g for 10 min at 4°C.
Attach a 0.45 μm filter to a 50 mL syringe, removing the plunger before attaching the filter.
Pour the lentivirus supernatant from the 50 mL tube into syringe. Put the plunger into the syringe and gently push it down into a new 50 mL tube.
Pause point: The lentivirus supernatant can be aliquoted into an appropriate volume and frozen at -80°C until needed.
Lentivirus transduction on C3H/10T1/2 cells. Troubleshooting 1.

Note: The day before the transduction, two 6-cm plates must be prepared with 1 × 106 C3H/10T1/2 cells.
Take an aliquot of lentivirus supernatant out of the -80°C freezer and thaw it on ice.
Once the lentivirus supernatant is thawed, add 4 μL of 8 mg/mL polybrene to 4 mL lentivirus supernatant to a final concentration of 8 μg/mL.
Remove the growth medium, directly add the lentivirus supernatant into cells in one 6-cm plate. Keep another 6-cm plate without any lentivirus as “no-virus control”
12 h after transduction, remove lentivirus-containing medium and add fresh, pre-warmed growth medium.
48 h after transduction, start puromycin selection.
Prepare puromycin-containing medium. Dilute the 10 mg/mL puromycin stock to a final concentration of 2 μg/mL. The puromycin concentration required for selection in different mammalian cells must be empirically determined (recommended 2–10 μg/mL for mammalian cells).
Retrieve the transduction cells from the incubator. Aspirate medium and wash cells with PBS twice. Add the puromycin-containing medium into the transduction plates, including the no-virus control plate.
Keep changing the puromycin-containing medium every three days until 100% of cells in the “no-virus control” die. It takes 7–10 days for the no-virus control cells to be killed by puromycin.
The puromycin-resistant cells are termed fibroblast_control, which stably integrated with Tet-on MyoD cassette but without adding doxycycline. Collect and freeze down a portion of the cells in DMSO.
Induce expression of MyoD.
Prepare doxycycline-containing medium. Dilute the 20 mg/mL doxycycline stock to a final concentration of 2 μg/mL.
Induction of MyoD.
Retrieve the fibroblast_control cells from the incubator.
Aspirate medium and wash cells with PBS twice.
Add the doxycycline-containing medium into cells to induce MyoD expression, which are termed fibroblast_MyoD. The cells are expanded in 15-cm plates and grow to be 70%–80% confluent (∼1 × 107 cells per plate).

Critical: After induction, it needs to confirm the expression of the tagged protein through immunoblot or immunofluorescence experiments using the anti-FLAG antibody.
BL-HiChIP (bridge linker-HiChIP)
Timing: 1 week
During this step, fibroblast_MyoD cells will be dual-crosslinked with ethylene glycol bis(succinimidylsuccinate) (EGS) and formaldehyde, then followed by HiChIP experiment with some modification containing enzyme digestion and ligation of bridge linker. For the BL-HiChIP of MyoD, the amount of the cells should be around 1×108.
Cell harvest and dual-crosslinking.
Critical: The EGS and formaldehyde are toxic, wear gloves, mask and dispose properly.
Prepare 1.5 mM EGS solution in a fume hood by dissolving 0.0684 g of EGS in 0.5 mL of DMSO, mix it well until the solution is clear. Mix the EGS/DMSO with 100 mL pre-warmed PBS (37°C) to a final concentration of 1.5 mM and then place the EGS solution at 25°C until use.
Prepare 1 × PBS∗ buffer by dissolving two tablets of proteinase inhibitor into chilled 50 mL 1 × PBS buffer and mix with rotation to ensure the solution becomes clear. Place the buffer on ice until use.
Retrieve the fibroblast_MyoD cells from the incubator. Remove the medium and wash cells with 1× PBS twice. Add 2 mL of trypsin-EDTA to plates. Incubate the plates at 37°C for 5 min.
Add 3 mL of pre-warmed doxycycline-containing medium to inactive trypsin. Collect the suspension into a 15 mL tube. Every two plates of cells were collected into one tube.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min.
Aspirate supernatant and resuspend the pellet with 5 mL of 1× PBS. Pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min.

Aspirate supernatant and resuspend the pellet with 13.865 mL of freshly prepared EGS solution. Pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other. Mix the cell with rotation for 45 min at 25°C.
Add 0.385 mL of 37% formaldehyde to the fixative solution to a final concentration of 1%. Mix the solution with rotation for 10 min at 25°C.
Quench the crosslink reaction by adding 0.75 mL 2.5 M glycine to the fixative solution to a final concentration of 125 mM, with rotation for 5 min at 25°C.
Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 25°C.
Discard the supernatant in a waste container and resuspend the pellet with 10 mL of chilled 1× PBS∗ buffer. Centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the supernatant.
Pause point: The cell pellets can be stored at -80°C for up to 6 months.
Cell lysis.
If the pellets are kept in -80°C, thaw them first on ice. Then lyse the cell (∼108) in 8 mL Hi-C lysis buffer with one tablet proteinase inhibitor and pipet up and down 5–6 times and split equally into eight 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes (1 mL/tube), each containing ∼107 cells. The following reactions are kept in the same one tube.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_14.csv
Incubate the cells at 4°C for 20 min with rotation. Centrifuge the solution at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C and discard the cell lysis buffer.

Note: The amount of Hi-C lysis buffer should be adjusted based on the cell number to ensure sufficient lysis. Check cell morphology under an inverted bright-view microscope after lysis step to ensure that the cells are completely lysed. Cell nucleus should become enlarged and transparent otherwise, repeat step 10a and 10b twice more for another two rounds of cell lysis.
Prepare the buffer 1, resuspend the cell pellets with buffer 1 and pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other. Then centrifuge the solution at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_15.csv
Permeabilization with SDS.
Prepare SDS solution in 1.5 mL tube (1 mL/tube, 8 tubes). Mix with vortex and pre-incubate at 62°C in an Eppendorf MixMate.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_16.csv
Aspirate the buffer 1 and resuspend the cell pellets in pre-warmed SDS buffer. Incubate at 62°C for 10 min in an Eppendorf MixMate.
After heating, add 200 μL of 10% Triton X-100 to quench SDS. Mix well by pipetting up and down and incubate on ice for 10 min. Then centrifuge at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Digestion with AluI. Troubleshooting 2.
Wash the pellets twice with PBST buffer, centrifuge at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Prepare the buffer 2, resuspend the cell pellets with buffer 2 and pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other. Then centrifuge the solution at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_17.csv
Prepare digestion reaction in 15 mL tube. Place the reaction on ice until use.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_18.csv

After centrifuging, resuspend the pellets with 1 mL digestion reaction and pipette up and down to ensure all cells are separated. Then incubate at 37°C for 12 h with shaking at 1200 rpm 15 s/pause 2 min in an Eppendorf MixMate.
Note: the amount of enzyme is dependent on cell amount, here 1×107∼3×107 cells require 600 U AluI.
Inactivation of AluI. The next day, incubate the solution at 62°C for 20 min.
Preparation of antibody-coated magnetic beads.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3000-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Three quality control checkpoints are shown with DNA distribution profile in BL-HiChIP protocol
(A) The AluI digestion DNA fragment distribution, with a peak at 1.5 kb.
(B) The ligation DNA fragment distribution, with a peak at 3 kb.
(C) The BL-HiCIP DNA fragment distribution, with a peak at 2 kb. FU: fluorescence units.
Transfer 150 μL of resuspend protein G magnetic beads to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Place the tube on a magnetic rack for 1 min. Then, discard the supernatant and wash the beads three times with 1 mL PBST buffer.
Resuspend the beads in 200 μL of PBST buffer, add 40 μg of the antibody into the tube, and mix with rotation at 4°C for more than 6 h.
Note: Protein G magnetic beads have a binding capacity of 240 ng IgG per μL beads. ChIP-seq of transcription factor requires 10–20 μg of antibody. For BL-HiChIP of transcription factor, it requires 20–40 μg of antibody (for example: anti-CTCF: 20 μg; anti-FLAG: 40 μg).
3′ dATP tailing.
Prepare A-tailing mix in 15 mL tube. Place the reaction on ice until use.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_19.csv
After the inactivation of AluI, wash the pellets three times with PBST buffer, and centrifuge at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.

Critical: At this point, take 10 μL of resuspended solution as digestion material for quality check of the digestion efficient (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A). Place the solution at -20°C until use.
After centrifuging, resuspend the pellets with 0.8 mL A-tailing mix and pipette up and down to ensure all cells are separated. Then incubate at 37°C for 90 min with shaking at 1200 rpm 15 s/pause 2 min in an Eppendorf MixMate.
Ligation with bridge linker. Troubleshooting 3.
After 3′ dATP tailing, wash the pellets three times with PBST buffer, centrifuge at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Prepare the buffer 3, resuspend the cell pellets with buffer 3 and pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other. Then centrifuge the solution at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_20.csv
Prepare the ligation mix in 15 mL tube. Place the reaction on ice until use.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_21.csv
After centrifuging, resuspend the pellets with 1.2 mL ligation mix and pipette up and down to ensure all cells are separated. Then incubate at 16°C for 6 h with shaking at 1200 rpm 15 s/pause 2 min in an Eppendorf MixMate.
Exonuclease digestion.
After ligation, wash the pellets three times with PBST buffer, centrifuge at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Prepare the exonuclease mix in 15 mL tube. Place the reaction on ice until use.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_22.csv
After centrifuging, resuspend the pellets with 0.6 mL exonuclease digestion reaction and pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other. Then incubate at 37°C for 1 h with shaking at 1200 rpm 15 s/pause 2 min in an Eppendorf MixMate.
Sonication, pre-clearing and immunoprecipitation. Troubleshooting 4.

After treating with exonuclease, wash the pellets three times with PBST buffer and twice with 0.1% (wt/vol) SDS FA buffer to release chromatin, centrifuge at 2000 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Critical: At this point, take 20 μL of resuspended solution as ligation material for quality check of the ligation efficiency (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). Place the solution at -20°C until use.
Resuspend all chromatin pellets in 3 mL 0.1% (wt/vol) SDS FA buffer containing proteinase inhibitor and pipette up and down to make sure all cells are separated from each other. Add 1 mL of chromatin solution to three 15 mL round bottom tube and place the chromatin solution on ice.
Shear the chromatin on a sonication system using optimized parameters. We used an amplitude of 34%; time of 2 min 30 s; and 20 s ON and 30 s OFF.
Note: This step aims to shear the chromatin into small fragments in order to immunoprecipitate with the antibody. The shearing size of chromatin is suggested to be longer than 1 kb.
Centrifuge the sonicated chromatin at 16000 × g for 15 min at 4°C.
Wash 150 μL of resuspend protein G magnetic beads with 1 mL of 1 × PBST buffer three times and split equally into three 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes (50 μL/tube). Add the supernatant of sonicated chromatin to the tube (1 mL/tube) to resuspend the beads. Pre-clearing of chromatin with rotation at 4°C for 1 h to remove nonspecific binding of chromatin to beads.
Note: After pre-clearing, take 10 μL of precleared chromatin solution as input material for quality check of sonication. Place the solution at -20°C until use.

After pre-clearing, wash the antibody-coated magnetic beads (from step 13) three times with 1 mL of 1 × PBST buffer and split equally into three 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes. Next, resuspend the antibody-coated magnetic beads with precleared chromatin solution from step 17e (1 mL/tube). Rotate the tube at 4°C overnight (more than 8 h).
Reverse crosslinking and DNA purification. Troubleshooting 5.
The next day, combine the immunoprecipitation beads of three tubes into one tube, then wash the beads three times with ChIP wash buffer 1, twice with ChIP wash buffer 2, twice with ChIP wash buffer 3 and twice with ChIP wash buffer 4, separately.
Place the tube on the magnetic rack for 1 min. Discard the supernatant and resuspend the beads in 200 μL of DNA elution buffer. Place the tube in an Eppendorf MixMate with shaking (900 rpm) at 65°C for 30 min.
Place the tube on the magnetic rack for 1 min and transfer the 200 μL of DNA elution buffer (contains protein-chromatin DNA complex) to a new 1.5 mL tube.
Repeat step b and c twice and combine the DNA elution buffer, totally 600 μL.
Add 10 μL of Proteinase K to 600 μL of protein-chromatin DNA complex solution, mix and incubate at 55°C overnight for reverse crosslinking.
Note: All the samples for quality check (digestion, ligation, and input) should be digested with Proteinase K in DNA elution buffer. Then followed by the next steps.
Prepare four MaXtract high-density tubes by centrifuging it at 16000 × g for 30 s at 25°C.
Add the solution digested with proteinase K and an equal volume of phenol-chloroform-isoamyl alcohol into centrifuged MaXtract high-density tube. Mix vigorously and centrifuge at 16000 × g for 5 min at 25°C.

Transfer the supernatant (above the gel matrix) to a new 1.5 mL tube. Then add 600 μL of isopropanol, 60 μL of 3 M sodium acetate, and 1 μL of GlycoBlue into the tube for precipitating DNA. Mix the solution by inverting the tube and incubate at -20°C overnight.
Centrifuge at 16000 × g for 30 min at 4°C to pellet DNA. Wash the pellet twice with 1 mL fresh ice-cold 75% ethanol. Remove the ethanol and dry the pellet for 5 min at 25°C.
Resuspend the pellet with 20 μL of 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH = 8.0) and dissolve it at 37°C for 1 h. Measure DNA concentration using Qubit 4.0 fluorometer and take 1 μL of BL-HiChIP DNA to assay DNA size distribution (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Pause point: The BL-HiChIP DNA can be stored at -20°C for up to several months.
Libraries preparation for sequencing
Timing: 1 day
The preparation of sequencing library was modified from a previously protocol4[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4] with some modifications.
Tagmentation of BL-HiChIP DNA. Troubleshooting 6.
Cut the BL-HiChIP DNA and add the adaptor using Tn5 transposase from Vazyme.
Pipette and combine all the reagents into 200 μL PCR tube.
Mix well by gently pipetting up and down and spin them down to collect the entire reaction mixture at the bottom of the tube.
Incubate the solution at 55°C for 10 min on a PCR machine.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_23.csv
Critical: The ratio between the TTE Mix and BL-HiChIP DNA is critical for optimal reactions, and this ratio needs to be empirically determined. In this protocol, the amount of BL-HiChIP DNA was 16 ng and needs TTE Mix 3.7 μL.
Purify the tagmentated DNA following the manufacturer’s instructions of DNA Clean & Concentrator-5 (Zymo, #D4013). Place the tagmentated DNA on ice until use.

Critical: Take 1 μL of tagmentated DNA to assay DNA size distribution (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).
Streptavidin Beads pull-down DNA.
Mix the streptavidin C1 beads suspension well and transfer 10 μL of beads to a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Note: Streptavidin C1 beads have a binding capacity of 200 ng DNA per μL beads.
Place the C1 beads on the magnetic rack, discard the buffer and wash with 200 μL of 2×BW buffer.
Resuspend the C1 beads with 100 μL of iBlock buffer and incubate at 25°C for 1 h with rotation.
Wash the C1 beads three times with 200 μL of 1×BW buffer and resuspend the beads 100 μL of 1×BW buffer containing blocking DNA (∼500 ng). Incubate at 25°C for 45 min with rotation.
Discard the 1×BW buffer containing blocking DNA and wash the beads three times with 200 μL of 1×BW buffer.
Transfer 50 μL tagmentated DNA (from step 19b-add resuspend buffer to 50 μL) and 50 μL of 2×BW buffer to the tube containing the blocked C1 beads (from step 20e). Mix and incubate the tube at 25°C for 1 h with rotation.
On-beads PCR amplification. Troubleshooting 7.
Place the tube on the magnetic rack, discard the supernatant. Wash the C1 beads five times with 500 μL of 2 × SSC containing 0.5% SDS and three times with 200 μL of 1×BW buffer.
Resuspend the C1 beads with 20 μL 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH = 8.0). Place the beads on ice until use.
Use 10 μL of C1 beads as template for each PCR amplification (total two reactions) of the library.
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_24.csv
Run the PCR amplification with the following program:
table:files/protocols_protocol_3000_25.csv

Critical: The PCR amplification cycle is important for final library quality. The first 10 μL beads reaction is used for testing optimal number of PCR amplification cycles and then modifying the PCR cycles for another reaction.
Place the tube on the magnetic rack and transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube.
Clean up the PCR products using AmPure Beads.
Mix thoroughly and balance the AmPure Beads at 25°C for more than 30 min.
Transfer 50 μL resuspended beads to the supernatant (from step 21e), pipette up and down for 10 times and incubate for 15 min at 25°C.
Place the tube on the magnetic rack and discard the supernatant.
Add 200 μL of 80% ethanol to the tube. Incubate at 25°C for 30 s and then carefully discard the supernatant.
Repeat step 22d once.
Keeping the tube on the magnetic rack, air dry the beads with the cap open.
Resuspend the beads with 17.5 μL 10 mM Tris-HCl (pH = 8.0). Mix well by vortex, incubate for 2 min at 25°C
Place the tube on magnetic rack for 1 min and transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5 mL tube.
Measure DNA concentration using Qubit 4.0 fluorometer.
Critical: The library should yield at minimum 100 ng. Take 1 μL of library DNA to assay DNA size distribution (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Select the DNA fragment in a size range from 300 to 800 bp using BluePippin according to the manufacturer’s manual and followed by sequencing on Illumina platform with 150 bp paired-end mode.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3000-Fig3.jpg
Figure 3. Two quality control checkpoints are shown with DNA distribution profile in library preparation protocol
(A) The size range of Tn5 tagmentation DNA mainly falls between 100 bp and 700 bp.

(B) The distribution of library DNA is between 200 bp and 1000 bp. FU: fluorescence units.
Critical: The data resolution is dependent on depth of sequencing. In our MyoD BL-HiChIP data, 5 kb solution needs about 200 million reads.
BL-HiChIP data analysis
Timing: 1–3 days
Many analysis software and files need to be installed and prepared before data processing.
Filter the raw data using galore software.
>trim_galore -q 25 --phred33 --paired --illumina --trim-n --fastqc -o tmp_R1.fastq
>trim_galore -q 25 --phred33 --paired --illumina --trim-n --fastqc -o tmp_R2.fastq
Remove the bridge linker by ChIA-PET2 with “trimLinker” command5[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5] and obtain the .fastq files containing the sequences flanking the bridge linker. Troubleshooting 8.
>trimLinker -t 8 -m 1 -k 1 -l 16 -o ${output} -n ${name} -A ACGCGATATCTTATC -B AGTCAGATAAGATAT tmp_R1_val_1.fq.gz tmp_R2_val_1.fq.gz
Align the clean data to the reference genome, remove duplicate reads and generate contract matrices using HiC-Pro pipeline.6[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6] Troubleshooting 9.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/3000-Fig4.jpg
Figure 4. Two quality control checkpoints are shown with IGV tracks in data analysis protocol
(A) IGV tracks showing the overlap sites between MyoD peaks (from ChIP-Seq data) and the MyoD loop anchors (from BL-HiChIP data).
(B) Representative example of the tagged MyoD BL-HiChIP in comparison to Hi-C data derived loops which including the MyoD anchored loops (GEO: GSE157339).
>HiC-Pro -c ${HicproConfigure} -i ${Home}/01.trimLinker -o ${output}
Generate the .hic file for visualization with Juicebox software.
>hicpro2juicebox.sh -i tmp.allValidPairs -g ${chr_size} -j juicer_tools_1.11.09_jcuda.0.8.jar -o ${output}
Get the high-confidence loops from valid interactions by FitHiChIP.7[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib7]
>sh FitHiChIP_HiCPro.sh -C fithichip-configure-tmp.txt

Critical: The configure file contains these parameters including bing size, q-value and the loop size. For checking the quality of BL-HiChIP data, we also did ChIP-Seq from the same cells and analyzed the overlap between peaks (from ChIP-Seq) and anchors of high-confidence interactions (from BL-HiChIP). The results showed that 79.8% (4786/5993) of anchors overlapped with ChIP peaks (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A). The result is consistent with regular HiChIP data.8[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib8] In addition, we also compared the tagged MyoD BL-HiChIP with Hi-C data from mouse primary myoblasts (Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO): GSE157339).9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] The results showed that 93.8% (3932/4192) of MyoD loops exist in the HiC loops (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B) confirmed that the HiChIP data are reliable.
